ClsC_e59c5b1a.class_description: Astrophysical phenomena involving gravitational waves, including the waves themselves and their production in compact-object mergers.
ClsC_e59c5b1a.evidence_excerpt: Ripples in spacetime ... produced by ... merger of two black holes

members.entity_description: Ripples in spacetime produced by accelerating masses, such as merging black holes.
members.resolution_context: The discovery of gravitational waves by the LIGO observatory in 2015, resulting from the merger of two black holes, provided further evidence of the existence of black holes and opened up new possibilities for studying these cosmic phenomena.

members.entity_description: Astrophysical event where two black holes coalesce, emitting gravitational waves.
members.resolution_context: The discovery of gravitational waves by the LIGO observatory in 2015, resulting from the merger of two black holes, provided further evidence of the existence of black holes and opened up new possibilities for studying these cosmic phenomena.

ClsC_b74f9936.class_description: The observational infrastructure and landmark detection event associated with the first direct observation of gravitational waves in 2015.
ClsC_b74f9936.evidence_excerpt: The discovery of gravitational waves by the LIGO observatory in 2015

members.entity_description: Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory that first detected gravitational waves.
members.resolution_context: The discovery of gravitational waves by the LIGO observatory in 2015, resulting from the merger of two black holes, provided further evidence of the existence of black holes and opened up new possibilities for studying these cosmic phenomena.

members.entity_description: First observation of gravitational waves by LIGO, confirming key predictions of general relativity.
members.resolution_context: The discovery of gravitational waves by the LIGO observatory in 2015, resulting from the merger of two black holes, provided further evidence of the existence of black holes and opened up new possibilities for studying these cosmic phenomena.

node_properties.justification: The phrase explicitly dates the discovery: "by the LIGO observatory in 2015".

members.entity_description: Empirical reality of black holes supported by gravitational-wave observations.
members.resolution_context: The discovery of gravitational waves by the LIGO observatory in 2015, resulting from the merger of two black holes, provided further evidence of the existence of black holes and opened up new possibilities for studying these cosmic phenomena.

members.entity_description: Large-scale or high-energy astrophysical events and objects such as black holes and gravitational waves.
members.resolution_context: The discovery of gravitational waves by the LIGO observatory in 2015, resulting from the merger of two black holes, provided further evidence of the existence of black holes and opened up new possibilities for studying these cosmic phenomena.

ClsC_75ff1689.class_description: Concepts describing how the passage of time differs in strong versus weak gravitational fields near massive objects like black holes.
ClsC_75ff1689.evidence_excerpt: Time slows down near a black hole relative to observers further away.

members.entity_description: Relativistic effect where time passes more slowly in stronger gravitational fields compared to weaker ones.
members.resolution_context: This phenomenon, known as gravitational time dilation, causes time to slow down near a black hole relative to observers further away.

members.entity_description: Rate at which time passes in the strong gravitational field close to a black hole.
members.resolution_context: This phenomenon, known as gravitational time dilation, causes time to slow down near a black hole relative to observers further away.

members.entity_description: Rate of time passage experienced by observers distant from the black hole’s gravitational field.
members.resolution_context: This phenomenon, known as gravitational time dilation, causes time to slow down near a black hole relative to observers further away.

ClsC_63646064.class_description: Core physical theories directly tested, constrained, or developed using black holes, including gravity theories and candidate quantum gravity frameworks.
ClsC_63646064.evidence_excerpt: Black holes provide a unique testing ground for theories of gravity... and have inspired new ideas in quantum mechanics and string theory... such as quantum gravity.

members.entity_description: Scientific theories describing gravitational interaction, including general relativity and other models tested using black holes.
members.resolution_context: Black holes provide a unique testing ground for theories of gravity, such as general relativity, and have inspired new ideas in quantum mechanics and string theory.

members.entity_description: Fundamental theory of physics describing nature at small scales, inspired by black hole studies.
members.resolution_context: Black holes provide a unique testing ground for theories of gravity, such as general relativity, and have inspired new ideas in quantum mechanics and string theory.

members.entity_description: Theoretical framework modeling particles as one-dimensional strings, influenced by black hole research.
members.resolution_context: Black holes provide a unique testing ground for theories of gravity, such as general relativity, and have inspired new ideas in quantum mechanics and string theory.

members.entity_description: Hypothetical framework unifying quantum mechanics with gravity to better describe black holes.
members.resolution_context: This has led scientists to speculate about the existence of new physics beyond the realm of general relativity, such as quantum gravity, which could provide a more complete description of black holes.

ClsC_94db8a44.evidence_excerpt: Speculate about the existence of new physics beyond the realm of general relativity, such as quantum gravity... and string theory.

members.entity_description: Theoretical framework modeling particles as one-dimensional strings, influenced by black hole research.
members.resolution_context: Black holes provide a unique testing ground for theories of gravity, such as general relativity, and have inspired new ideas in quantum mechanics and string theory.

members.entity_description: As-yet-unknown physical theories extending beyond classical general relativity.

ClsC_d3b25cfb.class_description: Concepts dealing with the fate and characterization of information associated with black holes, especially in the context of the information paradox and what data about infalling matter is preserved or lost.
ClsC_d3b25cfb.evidence_excerpt: the information paradox ... raises questions about the fate of information that falls into a black hole

members.entity_description: A theoretical puzzle in black hole physics concerning whether and how information about matter falling into a black hole is preserved or destroyed, particularly in the context of black hole evaporation via Hawking radiation.
members.resolution_context: Both entities explicitly describe the same black hole information paradox concerning the fate of information in black holes and differ only in naming/detail level.

members.entity_name: information about the contents of a black hole
members.entity_description: The complete descriptive data of matter and fields inside a black hole.
members.resolution_context: The holographic principle suggests that all the information about the contents of a black hole is encoded on its event horizon, challenging our traditional understanding of how information is stored in the universe.

members.entity_description: Abstract physical information whose fate is questioned when it falls into black holes.
members.resolution_context: The information paradox, on the other hand, raises questions about the fate of information that falls into a black hole and whether it is truly lost forever.

ClsC_be26b1f0.class_description: Theoretical constructs related to the holographic description of black holes, where information about their contents is encoded on the event horizon and challenges conventional views of information storage.
ClsC_be26b1f0.evidence_excerpt: the holographic principle suggests that all the information about the contents of a black hole is encoded on its event horizon

members.entity_description: Concept that all information about a black hole’s contents is encoded on its event horizon.
members.resolution_context: The study of black holes has led to the development of important concepts in theoretical physics, such as the holographic principle and the information paradox. The holographic principle suggests that all the information about the contents of a black hole is encoded on its event horizon.

members.entity_description: The boundary surrounding a black hole where information is thought to be encoded.
members.resolution_context: The holographic principle suggests that all the information about the contents of a black hole is encoded on its event horizon, challenging our traditional understanding of how information is stored in the universe.

members.entity_name: traditional understanding of how information is stored
members.entity_description: Conventional notions about the localization and storage of physical information in the universe.
members.resolution_context: The holographic principle suggests that all the information about the contents of a black hole is encoded on its event horizon, challenging our traditional understanding of how information is stored in the universe.

members.entity_name: information about the contents of a black hole
members.entity_description: The complete descriptive data of matter and fields inside a black hole.
members.resolution_context: The holographic principle suggests that all the information about the contents of a black hole is encoded on its event horizon, challenging our traditional understanding of how information is stored in the universe.

ClsC_e097613f.class_description: Quantities that characterize the spatial extent of a black hole, typically parameterized by the Schwarzschild radius. This class includes both the radius itself and derived notions of black hole size.
ClsC_e097613f.evidence_excerpt: black holes is their size, which is typically measured in terms of their Schwarzschild radius

members.entity_description: Characteristic radius around a black hole at which the escape velocity equals the speed of light, beyond which not even light can escape the gravitational pull.
members.resolution_context: "This radius" is an anaphoric reference to the Schwarzschild radius described in the same context, so they represent the same physical concept.

members.entity_description: Characteristic spatial extent of a black hole, often parameterized by its Schwarzschild radius.
members.resolution_context: Another intriguing property of black holes is their size, which is typically measured in terms of their Schwarzschild radius – the radius at which the escape velocity equals the speed of light.

ClsC_b78e9fc6.class_description: Speed-related quantities that define the kinematic condition at the Schwarzschild radius, where the escape velocity equals the speed of light.
ClsC_b78e9fc6.evidence_excerpt: Schwarzschild radius – the radius at which the escape velocity equals the speed of light

members.entity_description: The minimum speed required to escape a black hole’s gravitational influence at the Schwarzschild radius.
members.resolution_context: Another intriguing property of black holes is their size, which is typically measured in terms of their Schwarzschild radius – the radius at which the escape velocity equals the speed of light.

members.entity_description: Fundamental physical constant representing the speed at which light propagates in vacuum.
members.resolution_context: Another intriguing property of black holes is their size, which is typically measured in terms of their Schwarzschild radius – the radius at which the escape velocity equals the speed of light.

ClsC_52738602.class_description: Entities representing stages and components in the end-of-life evolution of massive stars leading to compact objects or black holes, including the star itself, its remnant core, the nuclear fuel it exhausts, and the terminal supernova explosion.
ClsC_52738602.evidence_excerpt: Black holes are born from the remnants of massive stars that have exhausted their nuclear fuel and undergone a supernova explosion.

members.entity_description: A star with sufficiently large mass that its remnant can collapse into a black hole after a supernova.
members.resolution_context: Black holes are born from the remnants of massive stars that have exhausted their nuclear fuel and undergone a supernova explosion.

members.entity_description: The remaining core of a massive star after it has exhausted its fuel and exploded as a supernova.
members.resolution_context: Black holes are born from the remnants of massive stars that have exhausted their nuclear fuel and undergone a supernova explosion.

members.entity_description: Fusion fuel in a star’s core whose exhaustion marks the end of the star’s life cycle.
members.resolution_context: Black holes are born from the remnants of massive stars that have exhausted their nuclear fuel and undergone a supernova explosion.

members.entity_description: Catastrophic explosion marking the death of a massive star, preceding black hole formation.
members.resolution_context: Black holes are born from the remnants of massive stars that have exhausted their nuclear fuel and undergone a supernova explosion.

ClsC_f068ea02.class_description: Communities of trained experts who systematically investigate natural phenomena, such as the universe or fundamental laws of nature.
ClsC_f068ea02.evidence_excerpt: have puzzled astronomers and physicists since their existence was theorized

members.entity_description: Scientists who study celestial objects and are puzzled by black holes.
members.resolution_context: These enigmatic cosmic entities, characterized by their immense gravitational pull that not even light can escape from, have puzzled astronomers and physicists since their existence was theorized.

members.entity_description: Scientists studying the laws of nature who have been puzzled by black holes.
members.resolution_context: These enigmatic cosmic entities, characterized by their immense gravitational pull that not even light can escape from, have puzzled astronomers and physicists since their existence was theorized.

ClsC_a1931605.class_description: Fundamental structural regions that constitute a black hole, specifically its event horizon boundary and its central singularity where classical physics breaks down.
ClsC_a1931605.evidence_excerpt: The boundary surface around a black hole, known as the event horizon... The central region of a black hole... the singularity.

members.entity_description: The boundary surface around a black hole, often described as the point of no return, beyond which nothing can escape the gravitational pull and near which quantum effects can produce Hawking radiation.
members.resolution_context: Both entities describe the same black hole boundary known as the event horizon; differences are only in phrasing and type granularity.

members.entity_description: The central region of a black hole where classical general relativity predicts a point of effectively infinite density and spacetime curvature, with zero volume, and where known laws of physics break down.
members.resolution_context: All these mentions describe the same singular region at the center of a black hole, with the 'point of infinite density and zero volume/curvature' phrases functioning as characterizations of that same concept rather than distinct entities.

ClsC_e1ef7ace.class_description: Interrelated physical phenomena and processes describing quantum radiation from black holes and its consequence of black hole mass loss and evaporation.
ClsC_e1ef7ace.evidence_excerpt: quantum effects near the event horizon ... emitted by black holes ... causes black holes to slowly lose mass and eventually evaporate

members.entity_description: A theoretically predicted quantum radiation emitted by black holes from near the event horizon, which carries away energy and causes the black hole to lose mass and eventually evaporate.
members.resolution_context: Both refer to the same specific radiation emitted by black holes that causes mass loss and evaporation, just with different wording.

members.entity_name: quantum effects near the event horizon
members.entity_description: Microscopic quantum phenomena occurring in the region close to a black hole’s event horizon, causing Hawking radiation.
members.resolution_context: According to Hawking's theory, black holes are not completely black but emit a faint glow of radiation due to quantum effects near the event horizon.

members.entity_description: The process by which a black hole gradually disappears over time due to mass loss from radiation.
members.resolution_context: This radiation causes black holes to slowly lose mass and eventually evaporate over time, leading to the so-called black hole information paradox.

ClsC_e07be971.class_description: People, dates, and theoretical constructs that define the origin and formulation of Hawking’s prediction that black holes emit radiation.
ClsC_e07be971.evidence_excerpt: Hawking radiation, predicted by physicist Stephen Hawking in 1974 ... According to Hawking's theory

members.entity_description: The physicist who predicted the phenomenon of Hawking radiation in 1974.
members.resolution_context: Another mystery surrounding black holes is the phenomenon of Hawking radiation, predicted by physicist Stephen Hawking in 1974.

members.entity_description: The year in which Stephen Hawking predicted the phenomenon of Hawking radiation.
members.resolution_context: Another mystery surrounding black holes is the phenomenon of Hawking radiation, predicted by physicist Stephen Hawking in 1974.

members.entity_description: Stephen Hawking’s theoretical framework proposing that black holes emit radiation and slowly evaporate.
members.resolution_context: According to Hawking's theory, black holes are not completely black but emit a faint glow of radiation due to quantum effects near the event horizon.

ClsC_c3b65825.class_description: Concepts related to black holes, including the astrophysical objects themselves and the processes by which they form.
ClsC_c3b65825.evidence_excerpt: Astrophysical objects with extremely strong gravity ... and the processes through which black holes originate and come into existence.

members.entity_description: Astrophysical objects with extremely strong gravity, containing a central singularity and an event horizon, whose gravitational pull is so intense that not even light can escape and which significantly warp spacetime and affect nearby matter and radiation.
members.resolution_context: Both entities share the exact same name, type hint, and clearly describe the same general astrophysical phenomenon of black holes.

members.entity_description: The processes through which black holes originate and come into existence in the universe.
members.resolution_context: Both mentions use the same name and describe the same astrophysical process of how black holes come into existence, with no contextual differences suggesting distinct concepts.

ClsC_14d07e9a.class_description: Groups of people, both expert and non-expert, whose attention or imagination is engaged by black holes and related phenomena.
ClsC_14d07e9a.evidence_excerpt: Black holes have captivated the imagination of scientists and the general public alike.

members.entity_description: The community of scientific researchers and scholars who study black holes and expand human understanding of these cosmic objects.
members.resolution_context: Both mentions refer generically to the same community of scientists researching black holes, differing only in wording and emphasis.

members.entity_description: Non-specialist people whose imagination has been captivated by black holes.
members.resolution_context: Black holes have captivated the imagination of scientists and the general public alike for decades, highlighting that not only experts but also ordinary people are fascinated by these cosmic entities.

ClsC_abf91264.class_description: Conceptual and perceptual attributes ascribed to black holes, such as their complexity and aesthetic or conceptual beauty.
ClsC_abf91264.evidence_excerpt: marvel at the awe-inspiring complexity and beauty of these cosmic wonders

members.entity_description: The intricate and multifaceted nature of black holes as cosmic objects.
members.resolution_context: As scientists continue to study black holes and push the boundaries of our knowledge, we can only marvel at the awe-inspiring complexity and beauty of these cosmic wonders.

members.entity_description: The perceived aesthetic and conceptual appeal of black holes as cosmic phenomena.
members.resolution_context: As scientists continue to study black holes and push the boundaries of our knowledge, we can only marvel at the awe-inspiring complexity and beauty of these cosmic wonders.
